case_name: Muthavalli of the Jumma Masjid, Mercara v. Ganapathi

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 207 of 1956 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 207 of 1956. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated November 5, 1952, of the Madras High Court in Appeal No. 852 of 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated November 5, 1952, of the Madras High Court in Appeal No. 852 of 1948.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on January 11, 1962 by VENKATARAMA AIYAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. January 11. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR, J.-This is an

facts.text: Suit filed by the appellant, as Muthavalli of the Jumma Masjid, Mercara for possession of a half-share in the properties.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal against the Judgment of the High Court of Madras, dismissing the suit filed by the appellant, as Muthavalli of the Jumma Masjid, Mercara for possession of a half-share in the properties specified in the plaint.

facts.text: The facts are not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The facts are number in dispute.

facts.text: Joint family consisting of three brothers: Santhappa, Nanjundappa and Basappa.

anchor.surface_text: There was a joint family companysisting of three brothers, Santhappa, Nanjundappa and Basappa.

facts.text: Santhappa died unmarried.

anchor.surface_text: Of these, Santhappa died unmarried, Basappa died in 1901,

facts.text: Basappa died in 1901 leaving behind widow Gangamma.

anchor.surface_text: Basappa died in 1901, leaving behind a widow Gangamma, and Najundappa died in 1907

facts.text: Nanjundappa died in 1907 leaving widow Ammakka who succeeded to family properties.

anchor.surface_text: and Najundappa died in 1907 leaving him surviving his widow Ammakka, who succeeded to all the family properties as his heir.

facts.text: Ammakka died in 1910.

anchor.surface_text: On the death of Ammakka, which took place in 1910,

facts.text: Estate devolved on Basappa, Mallappa and Santhappa as next reversioners of Nanjundappa.

anchor.surface_text: the estate devolved on Basappa, Mallappa and Santhappa, the sisters grandsons of Nanjundappa as his next reversioners.

facts.text: On August 5, 1900, Nanjundappa and Basappa executed usufructuary mortgage over the properties.

anchor.surface_text: On August 5, 1900, Nanjundappa and Basappa executed a usufructuary mortgage over the properties which form the subject-matter of this litigation,

facts.text: Appanna Shetty obtained assignment and filed O.S. 9 of 1903 in Subordinate Judge, Coorg.

anchor.surface_text: and one Appanna Shetty, having obtained an assignment thereof, filed a suit to enforce it, O.S. 9 of 1903, in the companyrt of the Subordinate Judge, Coorg.

facts.text: Compromise decree: Appanna Shetty to enjoy usufruct till August 1920, then properties revert to family.

anchor.surface_text: That ended in a companypromise decree, which provided that Appanna Shetty was to enjoy the usufruct from the hypotheca till August, 1920, in full satisfaction of all his claims under the mortgage, and that the properties were thereafter to revert to the family of the mortgagors.

facts.text: Sale deed dated November 18, 1920, Ex. III: Basappa, Nallappa and Santhappa sold suit properties to Ganapathi for Rs. 2,000.

anchor.surface_text: By a sale deed dated November 18, 1920, Ex. III, the three reversioners, Basappa, Nallappa and Santhappa, sold the suit properties to one Ganapathi, under whom the respondents claim, for a companysideration of Rs. 2,000.

facts.text: March 12, 1921, Ex. IV: vendors rectified Ex. III by including certain items.

anchor.surface_text: On March 12, 1921, the vendors executed another deed, Ex. IV, by which Ex. III was rectified by inclusion of certain items of properties, which were stated to have been left out by oversight.

facts.text: Ganapathi sued for possession, contested by Gangamma claiming self-acquisitions of Basappa.

anchor.surface_text: On the strength of these two deeds, Ganapathi sued to recover possession of the properties companyprised therein. The suit was companytested by Gangamma, who claimed that the properties in question were the self-acquisitions of her husband Basappa,

facts.text: Subordinate Judge of Coorg accepted Gangamma's contention, affirmed by District Judge and Judicial Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: and his finding was affirmed by the District Judge on appeal, and by the, Judicial Commissioner in second appeal.

facts.text: Gangamma died on February 17, 1933.

anchor.surface_text: But before the second appeal was finally disposed of, Gangamma died on February 17, 1933.

facts.text: Ganapathi applied to revenue authorities to transfer patta from Gangamma to himself.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon Ganapathi applied to the revenue authorities to transfer the patta for the lands standing in the name of Gangamma to his own name, in accordance with the sale deed Ex. III.

facts.text: Appellant intervened claiming gift by Gangamma on September 5, 1932 and release by Santhappa on March 3, 1933.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant intervened in these proceedings and claimed that the Jumma Masjid, Mercara, had become entitled to the properties held by Gangamma, firstly, under a Sadakah or gift alleged to have been made by her on September 5, 1932, and, secondly, under a deed of release executed on March 3, 1933,

facts.text: Revenue order dated September 9, 1933, Ex. II: declined appellant's title, entered Ganapathi as owner.

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated September 9, 1933, Ex. II, the revenue authorities declined to accept the title of the appellant and directed that the name of Ganapathi should be entered as the owner of the properties.

facts.text: Ganapathi got into possession pursuant to revenue order.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to this order, Ganapathi got into possession of the properties.

facts.text: Suit instituted by appellant on January 2, 1945 for half-share and mesne profits.

anchor.surface_text: The suit out of which the present appeal arises was instituted by the appellant on January 2, 1945, for recovery of a half-share in the properties that had been held by Gangamma and for mesne profits.

facts.text: District Judge of Coorg held gift not established, abandoned in High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The District Judge of Coorg who heard the action held that the alleged gift by Gangamma on September 5, 1932, had number been established, and as this ground of title was abandoned by the appellant in the High Court,

facts.text: District Judge held title under Ex. III valid under s.43 TPA against release Ex.A.

anchor.surface_text: Dealing next with the title claimed by the appellant under the release deed, Ex. A executed by Santhappa, the District Judge held that as Ganapathi had purchased the properties under Ex. III on the faith of the representation

facts.text: High Court of Madras dismissed appeal on November 5, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated November 5, 1952, of the Madras High Court in Appeal No. 852 of 1948.

facts.text: High Court held s.43 applies, title vests on Gangamma's death Feb 17, 1933.

anchor.surface_text: the learned Judges who heard the reference agreed with the companyrt below that the purchaser under Ex. III had, in taking the sale, acted on the representation as to title companytained therein, and held that as the sale by the vendors was of properties in which they claimed a present interest

facts.text: Leave to appeal granted by High Court of Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied for leave to appeal to this Court under Art. 133 1  c , and the same was granted by the High Court of Mysore to which the matter had become transferred under s. 4 of Act 72 of 1952.

facts.text: Santhappa executed release deed Ex. A on March 3, 1933 relinquishing half-share for Rs.300.

anchor.surface_text: under a deed of release executed on March 3, 1933, by Santhappa, one of the reversioners, relinquishing his half-share in the properties to the mosque for a companysideration of Rs. 300.

facts.text: Supreme Court held transfer under Ex.III protected by s.43 TPA despite spes successionis.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that when a person transfers property representing that he has a present interest therein, whereas he has, in fact, only a spes successionis, the transferee is entitled to the benefit of s. 43,

facts.text: Ganapathi's title prevails over appellant's under Ex.A.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, Santhappa, the vendor in Ex. III, represented that he was entitled to the property in praesenti, and it has been found that the purchaser entered into the transaction acting on that representation.

Section 43 of the Transfer of Property Act runs as follows- Where a person fraudulently or erroneously represents that he is authorised to transfer certain immovable property and professes to transfer such property for companysideration such transfer shall, at the option of the transferee, operate on any interest which the transferor may acquire in such property at any time during which the companytact of transfer subsists.

concepts.interpretation: Applies to transfers where the transferor represents a present title though having only spes successionis; transferee entitled to interest acquired subsequently by transferor if acting on representation and for consideration.

issues.text: whether a transfer of property for consideration made by a person who represents that he has a present and transferable interest therein, while he possesses, in fact, only a spes successionis, is within the protection of s. 43 of the Transfer of Property Act

anchor.surface_text: The sole point for determination in this appeal is, whether a transfer of property for consideration made by a person who represents that he has a present and transferable interest therein, while he possesses, in fact, only a spes successionis, is within the protection of s. 43 of the Transfer of Property Act.

issues.text: whether the transfer was void and conferred no title because the vendors had only a spes successionis in the properties during the lifetime of Gangamma

anchor.surface_text: With reference to the title put forward by the respondents on the basis of Ex. III and Ex. IV, the claim made in the plaint is that as the vendors had only a spes successionis in the properties during the lifetime of Gangamma, the transfer was void and conferred no title.

issues.text: whether s. 43 must be read subject to s. 6(a) of the Transfer of Property Act

anchor.surface_text: The contention on behalf of the appellant is that s. 43 must be read subject to s. 6 a of the Transfer of Property Act which enacts that, The chance of an heir apparent succeeding to an estate, the chance of a relation obtaining a legacy on the death of a kinsman or any other mere possibility of a like nature, cannot be transferred.

arguments.claim: s.43 applies generally to transfers on representation of present title despite no actual title or only spes

anchor.surface_text: Considering the scope of the section on its terms, it clearly applies whenever a person transfers property to which he has no title on a representation that he has a present and transferable interest therein, and acting on that representation, the transferee takes a transfer for consideration.

anchor.surface_text: The argument is that if s. 43 is to be interpreted as having application to cases of what are in fact transfers of spes successionis, that will have the effect of nullifying s. 6 a , and that therefore it would be proper to construe s. 43 as limited to cases of transfers other than those falling within s. 6 a .

anchor.surface_text: But section 6 a and s. 43 relate to two different subjects, and there is no necessary conflict between them. Section 6 a deals with certain kinds of interests in property mentioned therein, and prohibits a transfer simpliciter of those interests. Section 43 deals with representations as to title made by a transferor who had no title at the time of transfer,

anchor.surface_text: To hold that transfers by persons who have only a spes successionis at the date of transfer are not within the protection afforded by s. 43 would destroy its utility to a large extent.

arguments.claim: Official Assignee v Sampath Naidu wrongly ignores estoppel principle

anchor.surface_text: This reasoning is open to the criticism that it ignores the principle underlying s. 43. That section embodies, as already stated, a rule of estoppel and enacts that a person who makes a representation shall not be heard to allege the contrary as against a person who acts on that representation.

arguments.claim: s.43 indifferent to fraud; amended 1929 emphasizes

anchor.surface_text: It is immaterial whether the transferor acts bona fide or fraudulently in making the representation. It is only material to find out whether in fact the transferee has been misled.

arguments.claim: Precedents like Alamanaya, Shyam Narain support s.43 application to misrepresented spes

anchor.surface_text: The preponderance of judicial opinion is in favour of the view taken by the Madras High Court in Alamanaya Kunigari Nabi Sab v. Murukuti Papiah , and approved by the Full Bench in the decision now under appeal.

arguments.claim: On facts, respondents entitled to s.43 benefit; title vests over Ex.A

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that when a person transfers property representing that he has a present interest therein, whereas he has, in fact, only a spes successionis, the transferee is entitled to the benefit of s. 43,

holdings.text: When a person transfers property representing that he has a present interest therein, whereas he has, in fact, only a spes successionis, the transferee is entitled to the benefit of s. 43 if he has taken the transfer on the faith of that representation and for consideration.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that when a person transfers property representing that he has a present interest therein, whereas he has, in fact, only a spes successionis, the transferee is entitled to the benefit of s. 43,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.43 as general rule of estoppel applying to any lack of title including spes; independent of s.6(a); supported by illustration, policy utility, preponderance of precedents like Alamanaya, Shyam Narain; rejects Official Assignee.

holdings.text: Section 6(a) and s.43 relate to different subjects with no necessary conflict: s.6(a) prohibits substantive transfers of spes successionis simpliciter; s.43 is estoppel on representations of present title.

anchor.surface_text: But section 6 a and s. 43 relate to two different subjects, and there is no necessary conflict between them. Section 6 a deals with certain kinds of interests in property mentioned therein, and prohibits a transfer simpliciter of those interests.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.6(a) substantive prohibition vs s.43 evidentiary estoppel; different fields; no rewriting to import exception; Vickers v Evans against adding words.

holdings.text: On the facts, the respondents are entitled to the benefit of s.43; Santhappa represented present title in Ex.III, purchaser acted on it; title vested on acquisition after Gangamma's death Feb 17, 1933; Ex.A release conveys no title to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, Santhappa, the vendor in Ex. III, represented that he was entitled to the property in praesenti, and it has been found that the purchaser entered into the transaction acting on that representation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts' findings on representation and acting thereon accepted; applies s.43 to facts; vests title prior to Ex.A.

holdings.text: Illustration to s.43 is relevant, not repugnant, and supports application to spes successionis misrepresented as present title.

anchor.surface_text: In this illustration, when A sold the field Z to C, he had only a spes successionis. But he having subsequently inherited it, became entitled to it. This would appear to conclude the question against the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Illustrations aid construction per Judicial Committee in Mahomed Syedol Ariffin; general terms of section encompass it; not to be rejected lightly.

holdings.text: s.43 deals with lack of title, not contractual capacity; estoppel inapplicable to minors' cases by analogy.

anchor.surface_text: But the short answer to this contention is that s. 43 deals with transfers which fail for want of title in the transferor and not want of capacity in him at the time of transfer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes title defects from capacity issues; minors cases irrelevant to s.43 scope.

holdings.text: The decision in Official Assignee Madras v. Sampath Naidu is erroneous and overruled.

anchor.surface_text: The decision in The Official Assignee, Madras v. Sampatha Naidu is, in our view, erroneous, and was rightly overruled in the decision now under appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ignores estoppel principle; irrelevant to fraud/representation; pre-1929 amendment wording; preponderance favors opposite view.

holdings.text: s.43 indifferent to fraud or innocence in representation; material is whether transferee acted on it.

anchor.surface_text: It is immaterial whether the transferor acts bona fide or fraudulently in making the representation. It is only material to find out whether in fact the transferee has been misled.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Emphasized by 1929 amendment adding 'fraudulently or erroneously'; protects transferee acting in reliance.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that when a person transfers property representing that he has a present interest therein, whereas he has, in fact, only a spes successionis, the transferee is entitled to the benefit of s. 43, if he has taken the transfer on the faith of that representation and for companysideration. In the present case, Santhappa, the vendor in Ex. III, represented that he was entitled to the property in praesenti, and it has been found that the purchaser entered into the transaction acting on that representation. He therefore acquired title to the properties under s. 43 of the Transfer of Property Act, when Santhappa became in titulo on the death of Gangamma on February 17, 1933, and the subsequent dealing with them by Santhappa by way of release under Ex. A did number operate to vest any title in the appellant.

outcome.relief_summary: Appellant's title under release deed Ex. A does not prevail; respondents' title under sale deed Ex. III protected by s. 43 of Transfer of Property Act upheld; no possession or mesne profits to appellant

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that when a person transfers property representing that he has a present interest therein, whereas he has, in fact, only a spes successionis, the transferee is entitled to the benefit of s. 43,

We accordingly hold that when a person transfers property representing that he has a present interest therein, whereas he has, in fact, only a spes successionis, the transferee is entitled to the benefit of s. 43, if he has taken the transfer on the faith of that representation and for companysideration. In the present case, Santhappa, the vendor in Ex. III, represented that he was entitled to the property in praesenti, and it has been found that the purchaser entered into the transaction acting on that representation. He therefore acquired title to the properties under s. 43 of the Transfer of Property Act, when Santhappa became in titulo on the death of Gangamma on February 17, 1933, and the subsequent dealing with them by Santhappa by way of release under Ex. A did number operate to vest any title in the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: But section 6 a and s. 43 relate to two different subjects, and there is no necessary conflict between them. Section 6 a deals with certain kinds of interests in property mentioned therein, and prohibits a transfer simpliciter of those interests.

We accordingly hold that when a person transfers property representing that he has a present interest therein, whereas he has, in fact, only a spes successionis, the transferee is entitled to the benefit of s. 43, if he has taken the transfer on the faith of that representation and for companysideration. In the present case, Santhappa, the vendor in Ex. III, represented that he was entitled to the property in praesenti, and it has been found that the purchaser entered into the transaction acting on that representation. He therefore acquired title to the properties under s. 43 of the Transfer of Property Act, when Santhappa became in titulo on the death of Gangamma on February 17, 1933, and the subsequent dealing with them by Santhappa by way of release under Ex. A did number operate to vest any title in the appellant.
